title: Can I send my self published book to a publisher? - Quora

response.answer_text: Short answer: no. Now let’s talk about publishers and what they are looking for. I'm going to assume you have taken writing classes and seminars and have written a spectacular, sharp novel that contains no grammatical errors, has no cliches, has a fresh plot, compelling characters, hooks where they are supposed to be, that you have inserted twists, that your pacing is perfect, and you wrote killer dialogue. I'm going to assume you know the market, what is expected in your genre, and have written the correct number of pages according to the guidelines. I'm going to assume your chapters are the correct length for the type of story you wrote, that the scenes are stellar, and that there are no POV problems. If you haven’t done all of that … don’t bother reaching out to a publisher. Remember your competition is every known and successful author in the world who are also contacting publishing houses and pitching their books. How can you compete with them if your book isn’t up to par? If your book is really ready, here's what you do: There is a difference between an agent, who tries to find a publishing house to take on your book, and an editor at a publishing house who also might offer a book contract. Let's start with the publishing houses. In the publishing world there are five major publishing houses: Penguin Random House (Penguin, Dutton, Putnam, Random House, Alfred A. Knopf, Doubleday, Crown, etc.) , Simon & Schuster (Poseidon, Pocket, Threshold, etc.), HarperCollins (Harlequin, etc.), Macmillan (St. Martin's Press, Tor, etc.), and Hachette (Little, Brown & Company, etc.) Very few of the Big 5 publishers and their subsidiaries accept unsolicited manuscripts. You must query them first, which involves you knowing how to write a killer one-page letter asking them if they are interested in reading more of your novel. If they are, they will request 3 chapters and a synopsis of your book, which requires you to know how to write a synopsis. Then you wait. I waited for 18 months once (and I had an agent) for Harlequin to send me a rejection letter. There are many, many smaller publishing houses. Yes, they don't have the power and reach that the Big 5 does, but you have to start somewhere. My suggestion is to scout around the Internet and find an agent that represents the type of book you have written. Query him/her and see if you can get a contract with an agency. Then let the agent do the job of shopping your book around to publishers. They have the contacts and the know-how. Yes, you pay them a fee from your sales. But you wouldn't have had any sales without them. And they don't market to the 'little publishers'; not enough money in that for either of you. Also, make sure your book is ready. Have it read by other writers and take their comments seriously. One good site to try is querytracker. com. That is a free website that lists agents and publishers and tells you which ones take which genres and what their requirements are and how to submit to them. Not every agent in the world is listed here but there's around 1400 of them on this site. Do your homework and find publishers on that site that take on new writers that don't have an agent. Query them. If you don't know what a query letter is Google it...there are many sites that show you how to write that letter. Smaller publishing houses may be more willing to take a chance on a new writer than one from the Big 5. If you are lucky enough to get a request for 3 chapters and a synopsis, and you don’t know how to write a synopsis … check out this blog: Great Synopsis Checklist | Writers In The Storm To get the attention of an agent or editor you MUST write a book they want to represent. With that said, only query the ones that represent the genre your book is in. The query letter is the industry standard. Learn to write a killer query that hooks the agent and makes him/her want to read your work. I always (even though it says not to) include the first 5 pages of my ms (manuscript) along with the query. If they are interested, they will read them. If they read the first few pages and I can hook them, I'll get a request for a partial, which is 3 chapters. So there's your in... a killer query and a grab-em-by-the-throat first five pages. Just make sure the rest of the ms is as good as the first 5 pages. The other way to get the eye of an agent is to attend local writing conferences where agents are setting appointments. Most times, unless your book is just awful, they will ask for you to send the first 3 chapters as a courtesy because you attended the conference. There's your in. Make sure your chapters are sharp and fresh. The conference has a fee, but if you can fit it in your budget it is well worth it in just the lectures and knowledge you are going to gain. Here is an interesting diagram of what’s what in the publishing industry. The Big Five US Trade Book Publishers Also, check this website out. It was updated on December 31, 2018. Discover the Big 5 US Book Publishers Check out my e-book for more writing tips: Write Better Right Now: Creative Writing Tips Write Better Right Now: Creative Writing Tips eBook: Jody Lebel: Kindle Store Only $1.99.

There are a few publishers who will consider a self-published book. There are not many, and they are typically small, less well-known publishers. Few agents will consider a self-published book because they tend to favour the larger publishers who won’t publish a previously self-published work. Some competitions also bar authors who have self-published, and some accept works from self-published authors as long as the actual submitted work hasn’t been published. Indie publishing is increasingly gaining recognition, though.  It’s a matter of looking carefully at the specifications provided by the publisher or contest organiser, and if they are unclear, send a polite email to inquire. In today’s market, finding an agent and/or publisher to take on an unknown author is a challenge. Many competent writers elect to self-publish because the road to market through a traditional publisher is long and hazardous, and plenty of excellent works never find a publishing home. There are tons of excellent self-published works out there (despite the fact that some will shun anything self-published and denigrate any author who considers self-publishing). Sadly, there are also a lot of terrible self-published works, and differentiating can be difficult (though sites like Amazon and Goodreads assist judgment by encouraging honest reader reviews). In an ideal world, all good quality written works would be taken up by a traditional publisher and self-published titles would all be correctly judged trash. But we don’t live in an ideal world. And technology and changes in the market have greyed the lines between traditional publishing and self-publishing, as well as making it harder to secure a traditional publishing deal. If you are seeking a traditional publishing deal, my advice would be not to self-publish. But understand the road is long and hard and you might paper your walls with rejection letters until you quit and accept that the only way your work will see the light is through self-publication. If you are prepared for the long haul, confident your work is good enough, and able to write good submission cover letters and a good synopsis, submit to agents - and I wish you all the best. But self-publishing is a valid option, and plenty of authors have made strong profits and achieved recognition following that path. Don’t let the detractors convince you otherwise.

Sure you can. Having self published a book gives the publisher information about the sales potential of the book. If the book has sold less than a few thousand copies, they’ll know to avoid it. If the book has sold tens of thousands of copies, they’ll know it has potential. Now, that doesn’t mean they’ll publish that particular book, but it does give you an advantage when pitching your next book. I had a self-published book that sold tens of thousands of copies (at the time), but I was looking to expand into bookstores. I pitched it to a publisher, and this lead to collaboration on a project, very similar, but not identical, to the self-published edition. I’ve since signed four publishing deals with the publisher, which is great for me, because it gets my books into bookstores, and it helps with the production and editing costs. When pitching to publisher, you really want to keep in mind what your goals are. The margins on self-published books are much higher, so the benefits to becoming professionally published are typically limited to production cost savings, access to better editors, and a (slight) advantage in distribution. There may be a promotional advantage, but often the author is still responsible for most of marketing.

The easy answer is the conventional answer: No. The rationale is simple. If you have self-published a book that has sold well, a publisher will view the available marketplace as that much smaller than if the book hadn’t previously sold any copies at all. In other words, if your book has a potential market of 1,000 buyers, and you’ve already sold to 500 of them, that leaves a greatly diminished marketplace for the publisher to plumb. If, on the other hand, your self-published book has sold only a few copies, a publisher is likely to look at it with a jaundiced eye, as in “It can’t be very marketable if not even the author has managed to wrangle many sales.” If it’s viewed as not very marketable, of course, a major publisher won’t touch it. Fortunately, that conventional thinking may be changing a little. Recently, some big publishers have taken a chance on top-selling, self-published books with the hope that there’s enough of a market still “alive” to generate strong sales, particularly in light of the publisher’s use of its own marketing and sales departments and the availability of foreign rights sales and film/television options. So, in that case, a good-selling, self-published book may be eligible for conventional publication. Similarly, a conventional publisher could view a poor-selling, self-published book favorably if the editor falls in love with the writing or the story or both and thinks he could position it more successfully than you did. But don’t count on it. The very best way to sell a self-published book to a conventional publisher is to rewrite, re-title, and repurpose the original book. If you’re a writer, that shouldn’t be difficult. Expand or sharpen the book’s original outline. Add a new beginning (opening) chapter or two. Sharpen and/or expand the existing chapters wherever it makes sense to do so. Add a few chapters more (it’s always easier to add entire chapters to expand a book than it is to add a few sentences here and there throughout the book) AND cut any sections of chapters that are dead weight. Finally, stick a new title on the cover sheet, even if it’s not your favorite. If you can produce a book that’s 40 - 50 percent different than the original self-published version, you technically have a new book on your hands, and that means you can ethically shop it around (or hopefully find an agent willing to do so for you) to conventional publishers. As a caveat, I would still tell prospective publishers that, while the book you’re pitching is “brand new,” it’s story line is based upon a book you originally self-published on (date). Then sit back and pray for good news. Hope this helps.

Self-publishing, as many people expect, is not as easy as it seems to be. Sometimes while self-publishing your book, it may cross your mind that getting your book published through an established publisher would have been way easier. But there are certain things you need to know to clear your thoughts about self-publishing. Niche Books Perform the Best: One of the mantras of self-publishing is writing a book with a well-defined topic with a target audience to focus on. One of the popular topics could be religion or maybe politics. Whatever the topic maybe, if it targets a specific audience it becomes a bestseller. Create a Unique Title: If you want your book to become a bestseller, make sure you create a title which is unique. People buy books on the basis of titles, a good title makes the reader buy the book to know about the storyline. Self Promoting your Book: There is a very thin line between being overly aggressive and being assertive when self-publishing a book. It is good to promote your book on social media networks, but it gets a little too much when all you do is a tweet about your book. Make sure that you keep self-promotion to a limit where people are excited to buy your book. Quality is a Serious Challenge: Make sure that whatever you write is original, genuine and of high quality. When self-publishing a book, you write up becomes your USP. Make sure that the write up is such that people after reading your book, recommend it to others as well. This will increase the sales of your book and will help in making it a bestseller. If you need to know about how to self publish a book, you can contact us and get tips on self-publishing as well as more detailed information on self-publishing a book.

You can, but you’ll almost certainly be wasting your time. Publishers are interested in books that sell. If you are submitting your self-published book to a publisher, it’s because it’s not selling in the sort of numbers you want. So the publisher will look at it, typos, clunky phrasing, plot holes and all, and then will look at the sales numbers, because once you publish, you have a sales record. And the publisher will say, “You managed to sell 235 copies of this book. Why should we spend thousands on it if you can’t sell more than 235 copies?” Now, if you’ve sold tens of thousands of copies, and for some reason still want to offer it to a publisher who will pay you much less per copy than you are making now, the publisher is likely to say, “Those are great sales figures, but you’ve probably sold it to most of your potential market by now so we don’t want to waste thousands on it. But when you write your next book, we’d be very interested.”

Contrary to other answers, the correct answer is: Nope. You can’t submit anything to a publisher. Publishers don’t accept unsolicited manuscripts - indie-published or not. You can query a publisher with your indie-published book, knowing that they’re going to ask about how sales are going, but you do not sent your manuscript. Being a smart fella, and always interested in making sure that authors get the most out of their publishing experience, my question to you is: why would you want to cut your royalties by 56%? You’re not going to get any additional services, support, or marketing by going through a publisher. You’re probably going to get significantly less. Just curious.

Most often not as the traditional publishing house will want certain rights which no longer exist because you self-published. “First Rights" and “First North American Serial" come to mind, and those rights are not for reprints. However, the book “The Martian” was first self-published - chapter by chapter - in a blog in 2011. The rights were bought by a publisher and the book proper was released in 2014, which is how the movie got made. A unique example, as it was not ‘truly published’, however. This most likely wouldn't have happened if it was pushed as an Amazon e-book, which would make the paper book a reprint. There are exceptions, but they're very rare.

You may contact many publishers who do not require an introduction by an editor with whom they are familiar. But not all publishers would be ready or interested in publishing something that is already in print. Still, there are some, and, after all, we only need one eager publisher to help us along. There may be some preliminary issues about the agreement that you presumably have with the firm that published your work. Assuming that that presents no legal or other obstacles, you may find reworking your text worthwhile. A publishing house that is ready to review your MS (manuscript) and is capable of providing editing and related help can be worthwhile to check out. For one such publishing house (of which I am the Edigtor-in-Chief), see http://Http://wisdopmmoonpublishing.com with links to the Mission Statement etc, in the column on the left. Mitchell Ginsberg, Ph.D.

LOL! Read that question back to yourself, preferably out loud. I'm guessing you mean: Can a self-published book be published by a mainstream publishing company. Yes, it can. No, it won't be. The odds of that happening is about equal to your chances of buying a lottery ticket and winning a few hundred million dollars. Literary agents are the ONLY feasible way to even get your book seen by a publishing company. Most reputable literary agents won't represent a book that is independently published an available via Amazon or other smaller book-selling companies. Good luck!! You can check out my books at my website: https://jamesrobersonnovels.com/.

It depends upon the publisher, so you’ll need to check their publishing guidelines. The Martian by Andy Weir was originally self-published before it was picked up by a mainstream publisher. My novel Driven was accepted for republication through a small press called Encircle Publication after being initially self-published. So the answer is not always, but sometimes yes.

Can you send a self-published book to a publisher? Obviously yes. But it’s not very probable that a publisher will want to touch it (unless it’s already quite popular), as publishers generally want unpublished books. A previous publication means at least a part of the market has already been served, excluding the possibility of selling the book to that part.

No. Period. Everyone needs an agent. Everyone. A publisher will toss your MS or delete it without an agent. And, unless your self published book has sold at least 10,000 copies, most agents won't rep you.

Do you mean, “Can a self-published book be picked up by a traditional publisher?” If so, then yes, it can. Sometimes a self-published book takes off, and then traditional publishers want to cash in. “50 Shades of Grey” comes to mind. Author E L James self-published it as “Twilight” erotica fan fiction, and eventually Vintage Books published it traditionally.
Of course. You CAN submit anything to anyone. But unless you’ve sold thousands of books (very rare for a self-pub), it will be a waste.
Most likely you would send it to an agent. Read the latest edition of Writer’s Market to learn how commercial publishing works nowadays.
